newsitem.title: NETHERLANDS: EU finance ministers reach budget, jobs deal.
newsitem.headline: EU finance ministers reach budget, jobs deal.

text.p: European Union finance ministers on Monday agreed a budget stability pact for countries joining a single currency and a resolution on jobs and growth, defusing a row that threatened economic and monetary union.

Dutch Finance Minister Gerrit Zalm told reporters after a morning of talks with his colleagues that a deal had been reached that could be presented later on Monday to EU leaders at their mid-year summit.
"We have reached complete agreement on the stability pact and the resolution for growth and employment," he said.
France and Germany, sharply divided over the issue, both said they were happy with the agreement.

Zalm declined to give the contents of the agreement, but EU Monetary Affairs Commissioner Yves-Thibault de Silguy told reporters a link would be extablished between a pact limiting budget deficits of countries which join a single European currency and one one growth and employment.
De Silguy also said the ministers agreed to authorise the European Investment Bank, the EU's main lending arm, to help small businesses and high-technology companies as a way of boostoing employment.
A special European Union summit on jobs was also likely later this year in the autumn to keep the issue of unemployment high on the EU's agenda.

The latest crisis in the EU's plans for a single currency erupted last week when France's new Socialist government held up routine agreement of the stability pact, a framework for keeping EU budgets tight after EMU is launched.
Paris wants more political control over economic issues and is keen to see jobs creation given a higher role. Germany is vehemently committed to budgetary discipline and wary of government intrusion.

The mark dipped against the French franc and Italian lira on on news of the deal. Brian Venables, a senior bond analysts at ABN AMBRO said the agreement underlined that EMU would go ahead, probably with a broad group of countries.
"What can derail it now?" he said.
